description: From Middle English misliken (“to displease, offend; to disturb mentally, peturb; to dislike, find distasteful; to be unpleasant; to be displeased, dissatisfied, or unhappy; to feel sorry for (someone’s misfortune); of fruit or a tree: to fail to flourish”) [and other forms], from Old English mislīcian (“to displease; to disquiet”), from mis- (prefix meaning ‘bad; badly; wrong; wrongly’, or indicating a failure or lack) + līcian (“to like; to appeal to, please”) (ultimately from Proto-Indo-European *leyg- (“like, similar; even, level”)). The English word is analysable as mis- +‎ like.

verbs.description: mislike (third-person singular simple present mislikes, present participle misliking, simple past and past participle misliked)

entries.meaning: To disapprove of or dislike (someone or something); to have an aversion to. [from 13th c.]
To disapprove; also, to be displeased or unhappy.
To become sickly or weak due to poor health; to waste away.

description: From Middle English mislike (“displeasure; hardship; sorrow; unpleasantness”), from mis- (prefix meaning ‘bad; badly; wrong; wrongly’, etc.) + like (“pleasure, will”) (from liken (“to give pleasure to, make happy, please; to be pleasant; to suit; (reflexive) to please oneself, take delight; (reflexive) to be pleased to do (something); to like; to approve of, be in favour of; to be delighted or pleased; to choose, want, wish”), from Old English līcian (verb): see further at etymology 1).

entries.meaning: (uncountable, archaic) Aversion or distaste for something; dislike; (countable, archaic) an instance of this.
(uncountable) Lack of comfort; discomfort; also, difficulty; trouble; or sadness; unhappiness.
(uncountable) The characteristic or state of incapacity, physical distress, or weakness due to poor health; sickliness; (countable) an instance of this.
(uncountable) Discontent, unrest; (countable) an instance of this.

description: From mis- (prefix meaning ‘bad; badly; wrong; wrongly’) +‎ like (“similar”, adjective).

adjectives.description: mislike (comparative more mislike, superlative most mislike)

entries.meaning: (obsolete, rare) Not like or similar; different, unlike.
